s.text: She has a brief epilogue in which she admits that her anti-consumerism conflicts with it but does it in a way that demonstrates that she hasn't resolved the problem.
Success as a pop academic requires operating on two levels--that is, making distinctly different arguments for pop readers and academic readers.
Success as a pop academic requires operating on two levels--that is, making distinctly different arguments for pop readers and academic readers.
If you can afford it, great.
If you can afford it, great.
A great book on her subject, rather than a good one, might have found a way to propose an economic ideal that would not lead as inexorably into a social nightmare as Schor's seems to.
If you can afford it, great.
If you can afford it, great.
Prime-time television is full of supposedly ordinary, typical families who live in fancier circumstances than anyone at the median income could afford.
A person would belong by virtue of doing something she loved and believed in, and by being enmeshed in a web of community, family, and friends.
The main point of Schor's previous book, The Overworked American (which can be adduced from the title), was less familiar than her main point here.
Even if you accept that lawns and cars and credit card debt and designer logos are pernicious, to attack them seems, as a writing project, a little easy.
